title: How to Make a Duct Tape Rose Tulip

steps.headline: Get your duct tape...It's sold in a bunch of colors so pick one or two of your favorite colors.
steps.description: Also get your skewer, wooden works easiest.

steps.headline: Break the skewer in half.
steps.description: Not completely needed...But most skewers are about 10 or 12 inches (25.4 or 30.5 cm) and your rose will look funny with that long of a stem.

steps.headline: Rip, or cut, 27 two-three inch strips of the duct tape.
steps.description: If it's two colors, 13 of each color. 27 is about how many it takes for a good-sized rose, you can use more or less depending on the size you want.

steps.headline: Take one strip and fold it almost in half so you have a triangle on one side.
Take that strip and fold the side with the triangle, fold the sticky side down so you have a non-sticky triangle on one side and then a bit of sticky duct tape on the other side.
Repeat steps 4, 5, & 26, more times, or until you run out of duct tape strips.
Wrap your skewer in green duct tape.
steps.description: That makes it a stem, it can stay just plain wood, but make sure it doesn't give splinters.

steps.headline: Start wrapping the petals around the skewer, making sure it kind of looks like a flower.
Take a strip of your green duct tape and wrap it around the bottom of the flower into the stem area, it looks cleaner this way.
Give, sell or keep your beautiful flower!
steps.description: It won't die and never needs to be watered!

text: Get your duct tape...It's sold in a bunch of colors so pick one or two of your favorite colors. Also get your skewer, wooden works easiest. Break the skewer in half. Not completely needed...But most skewers are about 10 or 12 inches (25.4 or 30.5 cm) and your rose will look funny with that long of a stem. Rip, or cut, 27 two-three inch strips of the duct tape. If it's two colors, 13 of each color. 27 is about how many it takes for a good-sized rose, you can use more or less depending on the size you want. Take one strip and fold it almost in half so you have a triangle on one side.  Take that strip and fold the side with the triangle, fold the sticky side down so you have a non-sticky triangle on one side and then a bit of sticky duct tape on the other side. This is now a petal. Repeat steps 4, 5, & 26, more times, or until you run out of duct tape strips.  Wrap your skewer in green duct tape. That makes it a stem, it can stay just plain wood, but make sure it doesn't give splinters. Start wrapping the petals around the skewer, making sure it kind of looks like a flower.  Take a strip of your green duct tape and wrap it around the bottom of the flower into the stem area, it looks cleaner this way.  Give, sell or keep your beautiful flower! It won't die and never needs to be watered!
